title: a wee yarn with gerry around the jawbox
story: HAVING spent close to  years behind the pumps of some of Belfast’s top bars, Jawbox gin founder, West Belfast man Gerry White, continues to win plaudits for the product that is the sought-after spirit throughout Ireland and Europe.We meet in the city centre’s Grand Central café where bottles of his product are proudly displayed on the ground floor – with the gin stocked of course in the exclusive top floor Observatory bar.“I was general manager of the John Hewitt for  yearswhich I loved, I absolutely loved it,” he recalled. “The John Hewitt is owned by the Belfast Resource Centre with all profits going to it, then on to community projects who wouldn’t necessarily get government funding. It was really satisfying, there were no TVs, no gaming machines, managing there was all about conversation.”Gerry spoke of how the initial spark of the Jawbox brand came about due to his “wee bit of entrepreneurial spirit” – the ‘spirit’ being his drink of choice.“In all the years I’ve worked in bars the only spirit I’ve ever liked was gin. I had the idea of producing my own gin, bringing out my own brand. If it didn’t work I was more than happy to stay on as a barman, I would’ve always regretted never giving it a go.”Gerry said the process took over two and a half years from the concept to getting the name registered.“I did come close to giving up but all the right people came together, the absolute best of the best, with Echlinville distiller Shane Branf, his head distiller Graham Miller and packaging and branding coming from Drinksology. Everything started to move dead fast.”The launch night of Jawbox took place in late February  – “a night of one of the worst storms, so I wasn’t hopeful people were going to turn up” – at the Linehall Library, with a little help from the then Lord Mayor Arder Carson.“I didn’t want to launch Jawbox in a bar, every other bar would’ve gone ‘Well, why didn’t you launch it in my bar ’ I wanted something ‘old Belfast’ and at the start Linenhall [Library] told me that didn’t really do launches as such. I loved the setting and told them I had the Lord Mayor on board – I just had to ask him,” he laughed.“I then went over to City Hall and said ‘Any chance of speaking to the Lord Mayor ’ The staff were brilliant and Arder came over and fair play as he likes a brandy.“The next day, when it was being rolled out, I think almost every bar in Belfast took it.”In the event, over  people turned up to support Gerry that night – “one of their own”Jawbox is now served in bars across Ireland, has its own mural in Kelly’s Cellars, is the go-to spirit at Belfast International Airport, is served across the water as well as its signature label displayed in over , retail outlets in England, Wales and Scotland.Recently awarded Supplier of the Year at the Institute of Hospitality Awards at Titanic Belfast, Gerry was one of five artisan suppliers chosen to showcase his product at a reception for Prince Charles and Camilla at the Grand Central on Wednesday.“The name comes from my granny, Maisie, Maisie Cunningham, who would always say to us ‘In my day we all stood round the jawbox and did our washing,’ as not everyone had the pleasure or the luxury of having their own shared washing area. Everything would have been washed in a big Belfast sink, clothes, dishes, the baby –everything was washed in it. People shared their stories, told their tales, it was their jaws going round the box. I always say to people to this very day, when they have parties, where do people go  The kitchen. Everybody stands around the sink.”It’s evident just how much pride and enthusiasm Gerry has for the product that has grown at a speed he never foresaw just three years ago.“The award for Supplier of the Year meant an amazing amount to me, it was my fth time being shortlisted, twice for Jawbox, always the bridesmaid, never the bride. It was fantastic.”The -year-old says the power to promote Jawbox via social media is “amazing”.“There are places Jawbox is appearing that I would never know. Philip Schofield posted a bottle to his Snapchat, everybody was ringing me saying ‘did you see it  Did you see it ’”Having grown up in C­onway Street and later Lenadoon, Gerry has his base just off Queen’s University Belfast. “Where will the next three years take Jawbox ” I ask him. He replies: “The States.”“You only get one chance in America. It’s a matter of making sure we have the right importer, distributor. Sean Muldoon and Jack McCarty from the Dead Rabbit are out there who are going to be so supportive. I used to work with Sean in the Northern Whig. “Just two weeks ago Jawbox was used as the reception drink for the Irish Film Festival in Australia, we launched in Sweden.”Inbetween “surprising” those who take part in weekly ‘Gin Jaunts’ every Saturday afternoon as part of the extremely popular Taste and Tour experience, Gerry hosts Jawbox gin evenings at ious hotels were he shares his passion with others keen to hear how Jawbox was born.“I was really surprised to see how many young people turn up to these events. I nearly dropped when someone asked me to sign a bottle recently.“What I set out to do from the start was build a legacy, make the product authentic, that’s why my signature is on the bottle. I knew from the start that the quality of this product had to be better than anything  out there.”

title: pips families provide helping hand to each other
story: NORTH Belfast suicide prevention charity PIPS has been to the forefront over the years in providing support to iniduals who are considering or who have at some point considered ending their own lives.PIPS also provide support to families and friends who have been touched by suicide, with their family group the driving force behind such support.PIPS Family Group Meeting takes place every Wednesday night from pm to pm in Tesco at Cityside.The group is currently made up of seven members, all women who have lost a family relative to suicide.Two such members are Patricia Perry, who lost her son Johnin , andAnne McKenna, wholost her son Broguein .Patricia explained how she involved in the group.“My son died  years ago. PIPS came to the house for the wake and I got talking to them,” she said.“They offered me the chance to come for some therapy sessions and to get involved in the family group. I went and thought at the time it was all too much. It just wasn’t for me.“A few years later I thought about it and went back. I met the other members and we have been best friends ever since.“The thing is we know exactly how each other feels. You can’t explain it to anyone  how it feels to lose a child.“There is one woman in the group who lost three sons and another who has lost two.”Anne joined the group six years ago when her son Brogue died.“For me, the group provides great friendship for me and I enjoy coming every week,” she explained.“When it is my son’s birthday or the anniversary of his death, sometimes I don’t feel like leaving the house but I would never miss a group meeting on a Wednesday night.“Really, without this group I don’t think I would be doing as well as I am today.“Every week, I look forward to a Wednesday night to come along and meet with people I now class as my friends.”As well as exchanging their own personal stories of heartbreak and loss, PIPS Family Group is much more than sharing their loss.Every year, members save up to fund a four-day holiday abroad with previous destinations including Amsterdam, Malta and Portugal. They also have regular days out, shopping trips and an annual Christmas dinner.“I think the social aspect of the group is very important,” added Patricia. It is not all miserable and we all enjoy our holidays and day trips to just get away from it all. We have all become really good friends.“We work closely with New Lodge Arts doing things like arts and crafts and doing social things with them really gives us all a bit of a lt.“Losing a loved one is dferent for each person. I understand the group might not be for everyone.“We all just sit and chat. We can talk openly about our loved ones we have lost and it helps us remember the good and happy times.”Due to renovation work at PIPS Antrim Road offices, the family group recently got good news of a room available in Tesco in Cityside, Yorkgate, where their weekly meetings will be held for the foreseeable future.Despite the success of the group, Patricia would like to see a similar group set up for men so that men can talk to each other about the subject.“The suicide rate in North Belfast is terrible. It is an epidemic,” she said.“We badly need a similar group like ourselves, but for men so that they can too talk to each other.“We have welcomed men before but some felt it just was not the setting for them.“I wish a man out there would do something. Men need to be talking.“As for our group, it is great to have this new room in Tesco. It is a good size and a lovely room.”PIPS Family Group are open to welcome new members. Contact Patricia Perry on  or PIPS

title: the west belfast chef making waves at the malone lodge hotel
story: JOBS in the food service industry are renowned for being intense and testing but also equally exciting, therefore, having worked as a chef for  years West Belfast man Liam Mooney’s journey in the culinary world has undoubtedly been an interesting one. In April, he took up the head chef post at the Malone Lodge Hotel, where he had previously worked as a Senior Sous Chef before a seven-year spell working abroad. Although his new role may be viewed as a veritable homecoming, it could well be his most exciting challenge yet.Liam first started his career in the industry working as a waiter in the Europa Hotel – a summer job that would soon see him step behind the line in the kitchen. Reflecting on those early days, the Clonard man said: “The passion of the chefs had for food, the flavours and the way they were plating stuff up really inspired me. It was good to see that buzz in the kitchen.“Yes, it is a stressful environment, but the guys all have fun. They all work towards one goal and they’re all one big family. It doesn’t matter what kitchen you go into, they’re all family –one person goes down they all go down, which just shows the teamwork. When I first watched the guys in the Europa it just bit me and I wanted to be a chef after that.”Liam’s flair for cooking and his desire to learn inspired him to gain chef’s qualications, and garnered further opportunities including the chance to work at the inimitable James Street South.He later went to work at the Malone Lodge Hotel, where his skills brought critical acclaim in  he became one of six finalists in prestigious European Chef of the Year Awards. Liam was the only chef in the finals from a non-Michelin starred restaurant and eventually picked up a bronze award for his five-course menu that showcased the best local and seasonal produce. His passion for seasonality and high-quality produce is something that has stuck with him to this day.“I like to stick to the classics,” he explained.“Classics are classics for a reason. Sometimes I’ll twist it as best as I can, but I always try to keep the flavours clean and seasonal. It’s basically just good food that everybody can enjoy. It doesn’t matter what your dietary requirement, we can cater for it.“We’ll always try to make a dish that is gluten free or dairy free so that we don’t have to tell people they can’t have it. We’ll twist a classic dish to more clean or refined flavours so that everybody can enjoy it.”When Liam left Belfast for Guernsey seven years ago he felt it may well have been for good. His move brought success, of course – he headed the team at Guernsey’s most popular restaurant, the Slaughterhouse – however, when the Malone Lodge offered him a new opportunity it was a challenge he could not pass up, and one he is meeting with his typical enthusiasm for food.“I’ve been bringing seasonality back into the restaurant. I’ve been making Macklin’s Bar back into a bar where people can come for a few pints and have chicken, ribs – bringing back real pub grub,” he said.“We’re making sure the lobby is buzzing again with people enjoying scones, teas, coffees and paninis – just having a bit to eat and drink and relaxing.“We’re bringing the restaurant back to what it was a nice hotel restaurant that is there for families, kids, and everybody so that they can have a nice sit down meal. It’s not just for customers who are staying in the hotel – it’s for the people of the area, people from all over Belfast, or people just visiting.”He continued: “The response has been very very good. I’ve come in at a crazy time with tour groups coming in, we’ve had holy communions coming in, but the feedback has all been positive. People like what they see happening and what they’re getting, and they like that they are getting good value for money.”Although Liam felt he might live in his home city again, he insists hiswas the right move. With Belfast’s ever growing food culture and tourism industry, it could not have come at a better time.“Belfast has always been a booming city – it’s basically like a mini London,” he said.“It is always evolving and the food is always evolving. We have some amazing chefs. You have people like Stevie Tolman, who is a Michelin starred chef at OX – I worked with him in James Street South – I think it’s amazing what he does. Every chef bouncing off each other is the whole point of it.“I think it’s brilliant for Belfast’s tourism and the city as a whole. We’re able to show how we’re moving forward to a better place. You can actually go out now and enjoy a nice meal. When I was younger you maybe went out for your communion and you were luckyyou got a steak. People are now trying dferent things, they’re experimenting with food, and they are opening their minds to the dferent things you can eat. There are a lot of Asian restaurants and a lot of other multicultural restaurants in Belfast, which brings a lot of passion and a lot of enjoyment for everybody.”He continued: “I’m happy that I’ve been asked to come back and take over the kitchen. It brings a lot of pride because I was here when it was the old restaurant and then I was here when it got done up.“It’s good to be able to show these guys in the kitchen where hard work gets you and what we can do together. I want to give a bit of guidance and teach them things that I’ve learned and the stuff that I’m still learning. I’ve been away for seven years, but I’m proud to be back. I would have come back maybe once a year, but I’ve always missed Belfast and I’ve always been a West Belfast boy, so I’m glad I got the opportunity.”

"[Ireland] is the tail that wags the dog on this and we need to make sure we can do more to build that good will in Ireland and build their confidence."The so-called Irish backstop, which would see Northern Ireland remain in some form of customs union with the EU after Brexit in order to prevent a hard border, has been the major sticking point in agreeing a withdrawal agreement between the UK government and the EU. Credit: Michael McHugh PA WireBy Andrew MaddenTwitterEmailJune   CommentsFebruarys agreement not on the table in Stormont talks, says DUPs Arlene FosterBelfastDUP leader Arlene Foster has said a rumoured "agreement" made between parties last February cannot form the basis for the latest round of Stormont talks.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland februarys-agreement-not-on-the-table-in-stormont-talks-says-dups-arlene-foster-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph incoming article.ece e AUTOCROP h Arlene_Foster_Stormont.jpgEmailDUP leader Arlene Foster has said a rumoured "agreement" made between parties last February cannot form the basis for the latest round of Stormont talks..pushMrs Foster was speaking following a meeting between parties at Stormont on Monday, with talks now in their fourth week.In February last year, it was widely reported that Sinn Fein and the DUP had reached agreement on a deal to restore power sharing.Read MoreFirst intensive phase of Northern Ireland power-sharing talks break up after  minutesColum Eastwood: Powersharing deal will have to be done this monthMay and Varadkar call for Stormont talks to ‘intensy’Since the collapse of the institutions more than two years ago, one of the main sticking points in the negotiations was Sinn Feins demand for an Irish Language Act.Last February it was thought a three-stranded approach to dealing with the issue was finally settled on by the two parties.It was reported that legislation was agreed comprising an Irish Language Act, an Ulster Scots Act and a broader Culture and Respect Act, however DUP leader Arlene Foster later publicly denied such a deal had been made.Following Mondays meeting, Mrs Foster reiterated her view that there was never any agreement and stated what was proposed could not form the basis for the current round of talks."Well of course that wasnt an agreement. As we all know to get an agreement everybody has to agree, and there wasnt an agreement last February. Very publicly there wasnt an agreement," she said."Obviously what we want to do is find a way forward that everybody is comfortable with, that everybody can subscribe to and thats what were engaged in at the moment."The DUP leader said the party was "constructively engaging" in the talks."I very much hope that we can continue in the constructive way that we have been engaging and we can find a way forward," she said."We are up for finding a way forward as quickly as possible. It has to be a balanced way forward and one that everyone in society can sign up to."Last week, the issue of an Irish Language Act made headlines again after more than  figures from the worlds of sport, music and politics signed an open letter to Leo Varadkar and Theresa May calling for legislation to be brought forward.On Monday, Sinn Fein vice president Michelle ONeill hinted that Irish language legislation is still a red line for the party."It is now time to move beyond that constructive engagement to actually delivering to bring about an Assembly and Executive again," she said."Success would look like an Executive and Assembly that delivers for all citizens and implementation of previous agreements. That is what we are determined to achieve in this new phase."

This figure is expected to rise during the latter half of  with the UK scheduled to leave the European Union on October .The trend mirrors the flood of applications for Irish passports since the Brexit vote.In , there were more than , applications from Great Britain. This more than doubled in  to over , Irish passport applications. The current minimum waiting time for a first-time passport application from Great Britain is  working days.Applying for Irish citizenship is a dferent process from applying for an Irish passport, but in order to get an Irish passport you must first be an Irish citizen.Irish citizenship can be acquired in a series of ways, including through place of birth, Irish descent, marriage, adoption or residing in Ireland for a particularof time. Irish citizenship is automatic for people who were born on the Island of Ireland before  or those with a parent who is an Irish born citizen." width"" "" rel"nofollow"  Justice minister Charlie Flanagan Charlie Flanagan, Irish Justice Minister, recently remarked at a Irish citizenship ceremony in April on the "signicant numbers" of applicants from the UK.More than  British nationals were among the , new Irish citizens at the ceremony.A spokesperson for the Department of Justice and Equality, when asked whether the signicant rise of British nationals applying for Irish citizenship can be put down to Brexit, said: "It is reasonable to attribute this steady rise in applications from British nationals over the last three years to concerns around the outcome of the Brexit process."Up until , British nationals made up just a tiny minority of those seeking to be an Irish citizen.In , the Irish government issued more than , certicates of Irish nationality, just  of those were granted to Britons.The following year, when more than , certicates were issued, only  were presented to people from Britain.But between  and , the numbers rocketed by %, from  to .The number increased again last year, when  people received Irish citizenship.So far this year, the Irish Department of Justice has issued  certicates of Irish nationality to British applicants.

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandRevealed: Five schools share the top spot in GCSE league table results data-dfpadtargeting"" title"Today, we publish our annual guide on the GCSE performance of every post-primary school here that undertakes the examinations " width"" ""  " title"Today, we publish our annual guide on the GCSE performance of every post-primary school here that undertakes the examinations " width"" ""  Today, we publish our annual guide on the GCSE performance of every post-primary school here that undertakes the examinations Carol McCann, St Dominic’s, BelfastTom Skelton, DalriadaGrainne O’Hanlon, Loreto, OmaghMark McCullough, Rainey EndowedBy Victoria LeonardTwitterEmailMarch   CommentsRevealed: Five schools share the top spot in GCSE league table resultsBelfastFive Northern Ireland schools saw % of their Year  pupils achieve five or more GCSEs at grades A*-C, the Belfastcan reveal.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland revealed-five-schools-share-the-top-spot-in-gcse-league-table-results-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece c AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailFive Northern Ireland schools saw % of their Year  pupils achieve five or more GCSEs at grades A*-C, the Belfastcan reveal..pushToday, we publish our annual guide on the GCSE performance of every post-primary school here that undertakes the examinations. The results relate to the   academic year and include the core GCSE subjects, English and maths.GCSE school league table - check out the full list hereThe five schools in joint first place are Loreto Grammar School in Omagh, Lumen Christi College in Londonderry, Dalriada School in Ballymoney, Rainey Endowed School in Magherafelt and Friends School Lisburn.In joint sixth place are Our Lady and St Patricks College Belfast, Wallace High School, Lisburn, and St Dominics High School Belfast.In joint ninth place are St Louis Grammar School, Ballymena, and Dominican College, Belfast.In th place is Assumption Grammar School, Ballynahinch.Four of the top  schools are all-girl grammars, while the rest are co-educational grammars.Grammar schools claimed the top  places in the league table.The top-performing non-grammar school was Castlederg High School, which ranked th in this years table with .% of pupils achieving five or more top GCSE grades. It was followed by St Kevins College in Enniskillen in st place with .%, and, both in joint nd place, St Catherines College in Armagh and St Michaels College in Enniskillen with .%.Dalriada School headmaster Tom Skelton said he was "absolutely delighted" with the results."Its a fantastic achievement for the staff and pupils involved," he said. "To take every child over the line with % five A*-C represents a lot of hard work and the support of parents as well."Two years ago we were % as well, so were delighted to get up there again. I think it reflects well on the school, the pupils and the standards set by staff."Mr Skelton said the league table "shows the success of the grammar school system" and he added: "Pastoral care is a massive part of it. We have a very simple saying, Happy pupils, high expectation, high achievement and thats it in a nutshell."The school is well led by a supportive board of governors."Principal of Loreto Grammar, Omagh, Grainne OHanlon, said she was "delighted" at its joint top ranking, the first time it has topped the league table."It is the result of the professional relationship and trust which the teachers establish with the pupils," she said. "Theres a strong, supportive pastoral Special Educational Needs and safe environment surrounding the pupils and thats fully endorsed by the parents."Its the overriding belief that our young girls are creative, talented and able, and with a lot of self belief and hard work they can achieve."Lumen Christi College principal Siobhan McCauley said her schools academic success is largely due to "the excellent relationships that exist between students and staff".She added: "The strong support of parents coupled with the hard work and dedication of the staff enables our students, who are well-motivated and enthusiastic, to perform at the highest level and thus achieve outstanding exam results."Principal of Rainey Endowed Mark McCullough said the results were enabled by a "three-way partnership between the school, parents and pupils"."Its a great accolade - we just work and do the best for them that we can," he said."Im absolutely delighted and would like to thank everybody for all their hard work."Principal of St Dominics in Belfast Carol McCann said that % of all GCSE grades achieved in her school were A* A."Our performance at GCSE is the highest it has ever been in the A* A grades," she said. "We are very proud of the achievement, which is down to the hard work of the pupils, staff and parents, who have worked together."Our Lady and St Patricks College principal Deborah McLaughlin said her schools joint sixth position was "testament to the positive attitude of our students, who are supported by our committed staff and our parent body"."Were very much a team," she said. "It is a balance between academic and extracurricular activities for students."Principal of St Louis Grammar School in Ballymena Sean Rafferty paid tribute to the work of pupils, staff and teachers."I would like to congratulate the pupils, teachers and parents for their magnicent effort. Its about hard work and dedication," he said of its joint ninth place.Principal of Castlederg High School Elaine McKelvey said she was "delighted" it was the highest-ranking non-grammar school in the league table."These results are testimony to the excellent provision for learning made at Castlederg High School by a highly dedicated staff, working in partnership with very supportive parents to ensure the best possible outcome for each young person," she said.Mrs McKelvey paid tribute to the hard work and dedication of staff during "a most challenging period for educational delivery within all schools in Northern Ireland, given the shortfall in capital funding and inequitable remuneration for teaching staff"."Most of all though, we are tremendously proud of our pupils and their achievements, noting the breadth of opportunity for the future that such excellent exam results have created for them," she added.The Department of Education said the information contained in the league table relating to GCSE results "does not provide a valid basis for comparing performance between schools, since it takes no account of intakes of the schools or of any other factors that may affect pupil performance".It added: "No single measurement can constitute a fair or accurate evaluation of a school, and the figures should be considered in the context of other information about schools and their pupils."

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandSearch for  Disappeared teen Columba McVeigh resumes again data-dfpadtargetingJon Hill of Independent Commission for the Location of Victims’ Remains at Bragan Bog, Co Monaghan, where a new search has begun for the body of Columba McVeighBy Rebecca BlackJune   CommentsSearch for  Disappeared teen Columba McVeigh resumes againBelfastA new search for Columba McVeigh - one of the Disappeared victims who was murdered and secretly buried by the IRA - has resumed.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland search-for--disappeared-teen-columba-mcveigh-resumes-again-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece f AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailA new search for Columba McVeigh - one of the Disappeared victims who was murdered and secretly buried by the IRA - has resumed..pushThe -year-old, from Donaghmore, Co Tyrone, was last seen in November . He is one of three of the Disappeared whose bodies have still to be found.A search for his remains started last September in bogland across the border in Co Monaghan.It was suspended in early November due to the poor weather conditions.Excavators willto a site at Bragan bog near Emyvale today to resume the search effort, the Independent Commission for the Location of Victims Remainshas announced.Four previous searches there have proved unsuccessful.Jon Hill, senior investigator with the ICLVR, said it has taken some time for the bog to dry out sufficiently to allow the use of machinery."Weve managed to do some preparatory work in advance of today and so were able to get down to the search proper straight away," he said."As I explained back in September, we are searching an area of about one acre in total which is smaller than some we have worked on in previous Disappeared searches but this is challenging terrain. "We are about halfway through the planned search area, but as before Im not going to put a precise time frame on how long well be here."Obviously our hope is that we find Columba at an early stage but as ever well have to wait to see."What I can absolutely guarantee is that the highly skilled contractors and forensic archaeologists working here will do everything they humanly can to get the result that we all know will mean so much to the McVeigh family and all those who support them."Last week Crimestoppers announced that an anonymous donor had put up a reward of ,for information that results in the recovery of the remains of the three outstanding Disappeared victims.The others are former monk Joe Lynskey and British soldier Robert Nairac.Geoff Knupfer, lead ICLVR investigator, explained the donated money will be ided equally between those who provide information leading to the discovery of Mr Lynskey and Mr Nairac."The search for Columba was under way well before the Crimestoppers reward was made available and it can only be claimed on the basis of new information that in the first instance goes to Crimestoppers and that results in the recovery of the remains of the outstanding Disappeared cases," he said."As Jon has said, we want to find Columba as quickly as possible, and as things stand that would be on the basis of existing information."If that proves to be the case and we find him then the , allocated to Columbas case will be ided equally between the other two, raising the reward figure to , each for the recovery of the remains of Joe Lynskey and Captain Robert Nairac. "I want to stress that for the reward to be triggered new information must be registered with Crimestoppers and it must result in the recovery of the remains."All information that goes to Crimestoppers will be given only to the ICLVR and no one  and at all times and at all stages it will be treated in complete and total confidence."Crimestoppers can be contacted via:    and anonymously at www.crimestoppers-uk.org. The ICLVR can be contacted via: -, International: +

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# Republic of IrelandEuropean election recount begins in Ireland South constituencyThe recount of all , ballots was ordered as Sinn Fein and the Green Party battled it out for the final European Parliament seat. data-dfpadtargeting"" title"There are more than  count staff and  supervisors counting the ballots " width"" ""  " title"There are more than  count staff and  supervisors counting the ballots " width"" ""  There are more than  count staff and  supervisors counting the ballots June   CommentsEuropean election recount begins in Ireland South constituencyBelfastA full recount of European election ballot papers has begun in the Ireland South constituency.https:www.belfasttelegraph news republic-of-ireland european-election-recount-begins-in-ireland-south-constituency-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news republic-of-ireland article.ece ee AUTOCROP h bpanews_eca-c--be-ba_EmailA full recount of European election ballot papers has begun in the Ireland South constituency..pushThe recount of all , ballots was ordered as Sinn Fein and the Green Party battled it out for the final European Parliament seat in the country.The counting for the -county constituency began on Tuesday morning, after a recount was officially called for last Thursday.Gardai have been providing -hour security over the ballot papers at the Nemo Rangers GAA Club in Cork over the long weekend.And we’re back at #IrelandSouth for the start of the full recount. Still optimistic, still hopeful that it won’t take the full six weeks predicted! pic SkRhEuSVzr— Grace OSullivanJune , There are more than  count staff and  supervisors counting the ballots, and Returning Officer Martin Harvey told RTE Radio he hoped that the count could be finished by the weekend, despite initial predictions that it could go on for more than  days.Sinn Fein candidate Liadh Ni Riada made the request for a recount and recheck on Wednesday night when just  votes separated her and the Green Party’s Grace O’Sullivan on the th count.Ms O’Sullivan tweeted on Tuesday that she was “optimistic” and “hopeful it won’t take the full six weeks predicted”.Despite a recheck of Ms Ni Riada and Ms O’Sullivan’s , ballot papers on Thursday changing the outcome by just one vote, Sinn Fein pressed ahead with the request for a full recount.Mr Harvey said on Thursday: “Having completed the recheck of Liadh Ni Riada and Grace O’Sullivan’s papers, Liadh Ni Riada has confirmed that she wishes to proceed with a full recount of all the papers.”After the announcement, he said: “It’s dficult but it can be overcome and we will overcome it and we will do it. But unfortunately it will take time.”He described it as “democracy in action”.And thanks to #Cork - Spent  days at #EUelections count, staff so good humoured, Returning Officer Martin Harvey a gentleman - A heartfelt welcome in the City, now I know why they say welcome to the real capital...And thanks to #TheCorkArms @cork_coffee @QuinlansFish ...— Mick WallaceJune , Fine Gael’s Sean Kelly and Fianna Fail’s Billy Kelleher took the first two seats in the five-seat constituency earlier in the week.Independents  Change candidate Mick Wallace looks set to take the third seat with , votes.The race for the fourth seat and fth – the so-called “Brexit seat” – has been tight throughout the count.

into the machine by herself, a court has been told.https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk child-unable-to-get-into-tumble-dryer-on-her-own-trial-told-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news uk article.ece dfd AUTOCROP h bpanews_f-e-c-c-bbe_EmailA -month-old girl who was allegedly put in an activated tumble dryer would not have been able to climb into the machine by herself, a court has been told..pushThe child’s mother said the toddler was not strong enough to be able to do so at the time.The witness also told jurors she would not make  accusations and said she was seeking “closure” for her child.Thomas Dunn, , is on trial accused of endangering the toddler’s le by putting her in the machine at his flat in Arbroath, Angus, and switching it on at a point around the end of  or the beginning of .The child’s mother, who cannot be named for legal reasons, earlier told a jury at Dundee Sherf Court that she turned around from washing dishes at her friend’s home to see her girl in the tumble dryer.During the second day of the trial on Tuesday, prosecutor Nicola Gillespie asked the witness: “Wouldhave been able at that stage… to climb in thereon her ownthe door was open ”The woman replied: “No, she wasn’t strong enough on her legs at that point.”Earlier, she told the trial how she heard two thuds which drew her attention.“I just instantly thought that she’d been put in itbecause of how loud it was,” she said.The witness described hearing screaming while the child was still in the machine and agreed that Dunn had initially refused to hand the girl over after switching the machine off.Asked about Dunn’s demeanour, the woman replied: “There was just no emotion. I felt like he felt like it was a joke.“But I didn’t and I was really angry with it.”The witness said it took five to  minutes for the girl to calm down after the event and described how the youngster was screaming and trying to get away from the accused, who was holding her.The woman also spoke of an incident around the same time of year when she said she saw Dunn moving to put his hand over the child’s mouth and nose.The court heard she told police in a statement: “Out of nowhere, Tom saidkids find it hard to sleep you suffocate them by putting your hand over their mouth and nose for a number of seconds until they go drowsy.”It added: “I was shocked. It came from nowhere, I just thought it was an odd thing to say.”Defence advocate Niall McCluskey put it to the witness that the incidents could not have been so serious since she had left her child in Dunn’s care following the tumble dryer incident.She said she disagreed and told the court: “I wouldn’t accuse someone or make an accusation like that…“It’s for my child so she can get closure as well.“I wouldn’t ly accuse someone of doing that, I’m not like that. I know I did make a mistake going back.”Dunn, of Hamilton, South Lanarkshire, denies three charges of assaulting the child between December  and January .Dunn also denies assaulting a young boy on ious occasions between April  and January  by placing a hand over his mouth and pinching his nose, restricting his breathing.The case, before Sherf Alastair Brown, continues.

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# WorldWorkers strike at world’s biggest Nutella factoryThe plant produces , jars of the chocolate and hazelnut spread every day. data-dfpadtargeting"" title"Workers are striking at the world’s biggest Nutella factory in France " width"" ""  " title"Workers are striking at the world’s biggest Nutella factory in France " width"" ""  Workers are striking at the world’s biggest Nutella factory in France June   CommentsWorkers strike at world’s biggest Nutella factoryBelfastFrench workers have brought the world’s biggest Nutella factory to a near-standstill in a showdown over salary negotiations.https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news workers-strike-at-worlds-biggest-nutella-factory-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news article.ece b AUTOCROP h bpanews_daedb-ce--f-cbffe_EmailFrench workers have brought the world’s biggest Nutella factory to a near-standstill in a showdown over salary negotiations..pushTensions have been mounting at the site in Villers-Ecalles in Normandy, where activists from the Workers’ Force union have been barring trucks from entering or leaving the factory for a week.The plant produces , jars of the chocolate and hazelnut spread every day — a quarter of the world’s production of the product.After six days of failed efforts to end the stand-off, Nutella owner Ferrero has started threatening fines for workers involved in the blockade, according to a company statement.Its war, anger is mountingUnion activist Fabien LacabanneBut that has not deterred unions. Workers’ Force says  of the factory’s  workers are taking part in a walkout to demand .% salary increases, one-time -euro bonuses and better working conditions.“It’s war, anger is mounting,” union activist Fabien Lacabanne said.He said the company agreed to a .% raise for the lowest paid workers, and one-time bonuses between zero and  euro, which unions say is not enough given rising living costs. Unions also complain of deteriorating factory conditions and increasing pressure to be more productive.Italian-owned Ferrero said it is trying to protect workers who are not on strike, and wants to resume dialogue — but not until the workers stop blocking the factory.The next negotiation meeting is scheduled for June .French workers frequently go on strike during salary negotiations and occasionally resort to more dramatic methods. The last strike to hit the Villers-Ecalles factory was in .The action comes amid anger among many low-income French workers at pro-business policies by President Emmanuel Macron seen as favouring the rich — and that prompted the yellow vest protest movement.

title: 20m new build ardnashee school former foyle college site
story: A £m new build school for Derry children with learning dficulties has experienced further delays which means construction work is now “unlikely” to commence before , it can be revealed.The Department of Educationconfirmed its intention to build a new school and college on the former Foyle College Junior School site on Northland Road last year, however, these plans have been blighted by setbacks ever since.Firstly, there were delays in the transfer of the site from the Foyle College to the Education Authority.Issues around ownership arose when the building was set alight by arsonists in July of last year which subsequently held up the demolition process.And having committed to work commencing in the financial year from April  to March , the DoH announced in January of this year that it would be pushed back until the latter half of .The Derry News has now learned that a revised business case has to be submitted by the department meaning the build is unlikely to commence before .Yesterday, a departmental spokesperson said: “The Stage submission for the Ardnashee School and College project has been approved by the Department however costs have escalated and a revised business case will now be required.“The preferred option remains to locate the new build school on the former Foyle College junior school site at Northland Road in Londonderry. The need for a revised business case means that it is unlikely that construction work will commence before .”At the beginning of  the Department of Education confirmed that the Northland Road site will be taken over by Ardnashee School and College.Ardnashee school provides education and pastoral care for up to  pupils, ranging from  to  years of age, who have learning dficulties and associated disabilities.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshPhoto: former Foyle College Junior School site where new Ardnashee School is supposed to be built.

title: derry family gears foyle hospice walkrun june
story: The family of a Derry woman who was nursed at the Foyle Hospice are taking part in this year’s Female Walk Run in her memory.Nina Boyle was a we, mother, sister and granny was diagnosed with Motor Neurone Diseasejust last year.This le limiting terminal condition that causes muscle wastage and brain damage and affects breathing, speech, swallowing and the ability to move.Nina was nursed at the Foyle Hospice throughout her illness and passed away there last Christmas Day.Her family said the care Nina received there was second to none.“Foyle Hospice is more than cancer care, it provides respite for ious illnesses, it offers caring support for families and patients, through shared experiences, day care, and counselling.“We found the Foyle Hospice and surrounding gardens provided a sense of peace and comfort, as well as allowing patients, family and friends to take time out and share valuable time with each other.”Nina herself was very grateful for the care she received and told her family she was ‘treated as a person and not as a patient"Nina’s sisters are now undertaking the Foyle Hospice Female Walk Run in her memory on Sunday June .“It is a way to help us express our title: BBC new Tide show in Strangford Lough
story: STRANGFORD Lough is featured in a new BBC series which explores one of the most powerful forces on earth mdash the tide.Tide, which starts on BBC Northern Ireland this Sunday, will take viewers on an epic journey across four continents.The programme looks at the worldrsquos strongest and highest tides, raging whirlpools and the worldrsquos oldest tide mill mdash dating from  AD mdash which was discovered at Mahee Island on Strangford Lough.Throughout this three-part series, oceanographers, scientists and surfers share their own unique experiences and examine the impact the tide has on coastal areas.During autumn more than  per cent of the worldrsquos population of light-bellied Brent geese make the long journey from Canada to Strangford Lough.Dr Alex Portig and bird watcher Graham McElwaine explain why Brent geese make this journey across the Atlantic Ocean and how their movements are influenced by the tide.Dr Portig says: ldquoI grew up on the lough and I have been used to seeing Brent geese all my le.ldquoIt is lovely to see every autumn, geese arriving, feeding and chatting away to each other. It is definitely an iconic part of the lough.In the late s, maritime archaeologist Thomas McErlean and a team from Ulster University stumbled upon the worldrsquos earliest known tide mill during an excavation at Strangford Lough.Discovered close to the remains of Nendrum Monastery on Mahee Island, Thomas recalls the signicance of unearthing this medieval tide mill.Thomas says: ldquoThis was a site we got so excited about, we knew we were changing the course of Irish archaeology and indeedhellip industrial archaeology. We were breaking new ground and it was absolutely wonderful.In recent times, Strangford Lough has become an important site for tidal energy research and in  the worldrsquos first commercial tidal turbine was built near Portaferry.The turbine is now being decommissioned and local marine expert Simon Rogers, who is working on the removal, reveals the impact the tide has on operations. Tide is a co-production made for BBC Northern Ireland, BBC Alba, SC, TG and Sky Vision..prettyPhoto

title: Delight at fishing retreat for ex veterans
story: AN ex-army amputee who has opened a fishing retreat near Clough for disabled serviceveterans says his gamble has paid off.Robert Maxwell, who lost his right forearm and suffered severe head injuries in a serious road accident in , has been overwhelmed by support since the facility opened last week.Robert is the founder of the charity Letrsquos Do Veterans Support. Based on a five acre site at Kennedyrsquos Lake, the retreat has been visited by disabled groups who abide by the ethos of lsquofishing for funrsquo.No lead weights or barbs are allowed. Once a fish is caught and photographed it is released back into the lake.Robert explains that with the help of his close aide and fellow veteran, Nigel Cree, who is a director of Letrsquos Do Veterans Support, the net has been widened and that an invitation is being extended to anyone within the local community who wants to try out fishing.While battling to overcome his disability, Robert discovered there was little or no help for disabled veterans available in his community.Facing an interminable series of bad news on his journey to recovery he viewed the opportunity to be given a role in the British Limbless Ex-Servicemenrsquos Association as his saving grace.Robert said: ldquoWhen I got involved I saw people much worse off than myself. Some veterans had catastrophic injuries. I began to gain qualications in helping other people in the same situation as me. This helped me with my own recovery and give me a focus.ldquoMy house is down by the lake. One evening I was sitting observing how peaceful it was and it got me thinking about how I could put the lake to good use. In hindsight, the idea saved me from myself.ldquoI got a small team involved and before we knew it we had been successful in attracting funding to construct a car park, create fishing stands and a foot bridge, stock the lake with indigenous course fish and install an eco-toilet with disabled access.ldquoThere was no stopping half way through and the gamble has paid off with a successful opening and an encouraging demand for bookings growing each day.Robert describes himself as ldquonot being a lsquotea and biscuits man and doesnrsquot like to stand on ceremony.He continued: ldquoI have been helped by a devoted team of helpers and I would like to pay tribute to each of them and I dedicate this achievement to them and the three other veterans I started with who gave me great encouragement.ldquoIrsquod also like to thank Alpha Concrete, Hamilton Brothers and Cunningham Stone who were exceptional in their work with memorial plaques which have been erected.Robert said he hopes to provide fishing workshops in the near future and to get more people using the retreat.He added: ldquoA lot of time and money has been invested and when strangers visit we would ask them to adhere to the rules. They can contact me to book a session and pay a minimum day fee.For more information on Clough fishing retreat and for other initiatives which Letrsquos Do Veterans Support carry out, visit www.letsdoevents.info or contact Robert on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Event marking Men’s Health Week
story: THE St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick is hosting a special event next month to mark Menrsquos Health Week.Between June  and June , the centre dedicated to Irelandrsquos patron saint will feature an exhibition of art, craft and woodwork by members of the townrsquos Menrsquos Shed.The shedders are busily preparing for the exhibition with visitors welcome to view the work on display and learn about the work of the organisation in the community.The Menrsquos Shed aims to promote positive mental health and wellbeing to men over the age of  with the organisation offering a sizeable, well-equipped workshop at its Ballydugan Road industrial estate.There, shedders make wooden items to order such as garden seats and planters and they also produce items for community and conservation projects, like bird, bat and owl boxes for the National Trust.The Menrsquos Shed also offers opportunities for people to learn new practical skills including art, wood carving, clay, copper and leather work. The shedders also sing, cook and enjoy copious amounts of tea, biscuits and craic.And when not busy making things, the men love to get out and about visiting other Menrsquos Sheds which is a great way to network and exchange ideas.They also take part in day trips and have been involved in a new community engagement programme at Hillsborough Castle. The local shedders have also been given a fantastic tour of the grounds at Castle Ward to see their very own bird boxes being installed.The Downpatrick Menrsquos Shed is open on Tuesdays and Thursdays between .am and pm and on Friday between .am and .pm.For more information about the work of the organisation and how to get involved, telephone   or visit the Facebook Page, @MensShedDownpatrick..prettyPhoto

title: Former chairman reflects on year in office
story: FORMER Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Mark Murnin has described his term at the helm of the organisation as ldquoabsolutely fantastic.Mr Murnin mdash who lost his Slieve Croob seat to SDLP colleague Hugh Gallagher at the recent council election mdash served the area for four years, with his term as chairman a particular highlight.Reflecting on his year in office, which took him across Europe, the United States and the Far East, Mr Murnin said he spent almost  nights abroad and that there were many high points over the past  months.Addressing the local authorityrsquos annual meeting last week, the outgoing chairman thanked his party colleagues, fellow councillors and staff for their support.But Mr Murnin said the joy of his year in office was tinged with sadness as a number of people across the district tragically lost their lives, including a council staff member.ldquoThere were many highlights along the way, continued the chairman whose time at the helm concluded with a major charity walk which raised over pound, for Air Ambulance Northern Ireland, Harmony Community Trust and Newry Gateway Club.ldquoIt was great to start off my year with the districtrsquos special olympians and to be with them again near the end of my term in office. They represented the district so well at Irish level and again at world level in Abu Dhabi, bringing home medals.Mr Murnin also referred to the success of the inaugural Be Active Cup involving soccer teams from opposite sides of the council area. He instigated the tournament and hopes his successors will continue with it.He continued: ldquoDuring my year we had the opportunity to salute Dermot Curran, one of our long standing councillors mdash in fact the longest serving in Northern Ireland mdash with whom we enjoyed a fantastic night.ldquoIt was also a pleasure to lead our St Patrickrsquos Day parade in my home area which was really special for me. We then had the Innovation Nation event, bringing many young people from our schools together to see the exciting advances in the business opportunities that are presented to them going forward.Mr Murnin said he was also involved in helping fundraise for brave Bessbrook girl Ellen Treanor and six-year Alfie Pentony from Newry who will both travel to the US for pioneering health treatment.Sadly for the former chairman, rain intervened last August and the annual Festival of Flight international air show in Newcastle was cancelled.On a serious note, he told those in the chamber that a great responsibility comes with being a councillor.ldquoAs you strive to make this district the number one place to do business and set up a home, itrsquos worth remembering that those across the council chamber are not necessarily the enemy mdash you all must work together for the betterment of our district, he said.ldquoDuring my recent visit to New York, I was able to see how investors view the world and it was interesting to see where they see opportunities and risks, in particular.ldquoOne of those was climate risk and the importance of it, with businesses looking at it from an investors point of view. As a district, this is something that we need to take seriously, and not necessarily just rising sea levels.Mr Murnin believes that increased rainfall is going to make a dramatic dference to the way buildings and roads are designed, also highlighting the need to look at alternative energy forms.He added: ldquoBuilding for the future and how a modern city should look like will also be important. One thing that struck me looking out from the observation tower at the One World Center in New York was that the city is surprisingly green as so many of the buildings have roof top gardens and trees. This is something we should look to replicate where we can..prettyPhoto

title: Foster sisters and Alex shine at schools’ event
story: THE Newry Mourne and Down Primary Schoolsrsquo Cross Country Championships were held in Kilbroney Forest Park last Tuesday.Jodi Foster was first in the P girls and her sister Kari was second in the P girls. Although both are EDAC athletes, they were representing Spa Primary on the day.Alex Robinson battled his way to sixth in his race with the top six in each race getting a medal. There was a huge turnout of over  runners and plenty of excitement for both athletes and spectators.Bann k and fun runWednesday proved something of a Murrayrsquos benefit day out as they participated with distinction in the Bann k and Fun Run in Banbridge.Dee was seventh overall out of  runners in the k. His time was . and good enough to win first prize in the over  category. Seamus Savage, again opting for a midweek race, also took part and posted . for th place and although Janine Murray wasnrsquot overly pleased with her time of ., which was slower than in the Les Jones k on the previous Friday night, she canrsquot be accused of slacking as she turned out for the Hill and Dale the next night.The secret of course, Janine, is not to always look to better your previous time, take them in your stride and the good times will come. Not everyone can race to their max all the time.However it was Dee and Janinersquos ever-improving and dedicated son Mackenzie who deserves top billing this week as he won the k run, crossing the line well clear in a field of  runners. With a gap of almost a minute over second place, he literally showed a clean pair of heels to everyone. Well done, Mackenzie.Hill and DaleGavin Hynds was once again the first of the East Down runners to finish the Moughanmoreround of the Hill and Dale Series on Thursday night, endorsing the thought that experience is a valuable asset, as he improved his place from last yearrsquos rd to th overall. That is positively the last reference regarding birthdays and age .Niall Gibney was next, maintaining his good form in the mountains, in th place, followed by Paddy McDonald and Janine Murray, who was making her second appearance in as many nights, following on from her k efforts in Banbridge on Wednesday, and Patricia Galloway the only other female member of EDAC to turn out.Newry half marathonMarguerite Robinson ended up being the sole representative of EDAC at Newry City Half Marathon on Sunday.After a damp, chilly start the temperature eventually rose to a more comfortable level. The out and back course went from Newry past Narrow Water Castle with a bit of a detour around an industrial estate to make up the distance.Marguerite was hampered by stomach cramps and was forced to battle just to complete the course as she was loath toout.The head wind on thetrip was an added burden, but she survived the mental and physical battle and recorded a time of ., and admitted she was just pleased to be finished. Well done to her.The race was won by the remarkable Tommy Hughes mdash the Marrakesh Express mdash now aged , in .., nearly two minutes ahead of the second-placed runner. Tommy seems to break records for runners in his age category with astonishing regularityNeil in good formNeil McCartan ran in the British Milers Meet in Manchester at the weekend, recording .. in his first ,m of the season. A good, solid run. He will now set his sights on the ,m at the NI  Ulster Championships at Mary Peters Track on June .Full steam aheadTrack racing dominates the weekends for the month of June with the NIUlster Championships spread over two weekends, according to age groups. The NIUlster Childrenrsquos Games are on this weekend as well as the Irish Schools. Good luck to all who are competing. For the others there is a raft of local and not so local events mdash details available at https:athleticsni.org FixturesGet out and get running..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 29%2C 1979
story: BALLYKINLAR mdash The future of a pound, racehorse owned by an Ardglass hotelier is hanging in the balance after a mysterious shooting incident near Ballykinlar army camp at the weekend.The horse, Northern Luck, is awaiting an operation to remove a bullet from its neck and until the tricky surgery is carried out its owner, Mr Sean Treacey, will not knowit will be able to race again.The incident happened as Mr Treacey was training his horse on Saturday. His young  year-old jockey, Sean Armitage, was giving the horse a work-out gallop in preparation for the Sligo race meeting when he suddenly felt the horse jerk.Moments later they saw blood trickling down the neck of the horse and after finding a small hole they realised that a bullet had done the damage. The incident happened near the army camp.Mr Treacey, who lives at Ardglass Castle, reported the incident to police and investigations began immediately. However, they have not discovered who fired the bullet.ldquoThe future of the horse is very much in the balance, said an unhappy Mr Treacey. ldquoThe bullet is lodged close to the horsersquos spine and my vet has suggested a very tricky operation is needed to remove it.ldquoWorse still, it could easily have been my jockey who was hit. He was in the racing position on the horse and had the bullet been six inches higher it would have hit him in the head.A police spokesman confirmed the incident and said that it had been established that the horse had gunshot wounds, possibly from a . bullet.ldquoOur investigations are continuing and we hope to be in a position to establish whether it could have been a ricochet or a stray bullet from the firing range, or a deliberate shooting incident, he said.LEITRIM mdash Road racer Tom Herron, tragically killed at the North West meeting on Saturday, was buried beside Leitrim Presbyterian Church on Monday. The mourners included many of his racing colleagues, who had flown from the Isle of Man to be at the graveside.The funeral service was conducted by the Rev James Johnston, who referred to Herronrsquos many qualities and the determination which had taken him to the top.Herron was the third motorcycle ace from mid Down to die in race accidents. The brilliant Killyleagh rider Brian Steenson and the up and coming Ballynahinch rider Brian McCombe were both killed in accidents at the Isle of Man TT.DOWNPATRICK mdash St Patrickrsquos Festival has the potential to become one of the most important and spectacular of its kind in Northern Ireland. That was the firm message this week from one of the men who spearheaded the highly successful four-day event in Downpatrick.Mr Frank Connolly said the amazing reaction from the public and the dedication of the -strong organising committee left no doubt in his mind that the festival was capable of becoming a crowd-pulling annual attraction.ldquoI believe strongly that this festival has laid down a tremendous  for us to build on for the future, he said. ldquoI would like to see it become the leading festival in Northern Ireland and there is no reason why this should not be the case.ldquoIt was unbelievable to see so many people enjoying themselves, young and old. The spirit is definitely there and local people can increase the size of the festival each year and have something to be proud of.The festival was given a firm nod of approval by Mr Eddie McGrady, chairman of Down Council.He said the event had been a tremendous success and showed clearly that the way is open for an extended and even more ambitious festival in years to follow.ldquoThis festival has shown what a small number of dedicated people can do. On behalf of myself and the people of Down District I would like to thank the organisers for producing an event for Downpatrick which everyone can be proud of, he added.BALLYGOWAN mdash More than  employees at the Belfast Ropeworks in Ballygowan, who walked out at the weekend in support of a pay claim, have ed to work.The men, all sht workers, downed tools on Thursday in protest over a productivity bonus offered by the management. However, the dispute has been settled and the firm, situated on the Moss Road, is operating as normal.A company spokesman said: ldquoThe men have accepted the offer and have all ed to work. Fortunately, the action only lasted for a limited period.PORTAFERRY mdash Declan Mackell sailed single-handed out of Portaferry on Sunday afternoon to go round the world. A handful of boats accompanied him out of Strangford Lough after he had enjoyed lunch at the Portaferry Hotel.ldquoYes, Irsquom probably mad, he admitted before he left. ldquoBut I see this outing as something that should satisfy my curiosity in the same way as my transatlantic trip last year.His -foot yacht dipped gently into the Irish Sea as the former carpenter tacked his way out of sight and got his self-steering gear into action for his first night at sea.Declan, who has prepared his boat over the last six months, will take in France, the Mediterranean, the Canaries, Atlantic and Pacic Oceans, Australia, New Zealand, Indian Ocean and Cape Hope before coming back to Portaferry.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Castlewellan Library, formerly the Market House, was officially opened by Mr Peter OrsquoHagen, chairman of the South Eastern Education and Library Board, this week.Almost pound, was pumped into covering the building into a library and the Board agree that the expense was worth it. They now have a site in a central position in the town, convenient to shops, bus routes and car parks.CROSSGAR mdash A new pound, for Lissara Presbyterian Church was opened and dedicated at a specialon Monday night. The extension is in memory of a former minister, the Rev Samuel Finlay, and was opened by Mrs Gladys Finlay.The Moderator of the General Assembly, the Right Rev David Burke, was the main guest. Also present were the Rev James Lamont, Moderator of Down Presbytery, and the Rev S A Matthews, church minister.M Dunlop, of Dunlop Bros, Saintfield, which carried out the extension work, presented the key to the church to Mrs Finlay, who performed the opening ceremony after which Rev Burke dedicated the extension. Following the special service the congregation were invited to the church hall for tea.STRANGFORD mdash The Department of the Environment has announced restrictions to the Strangford ferry service because of fuel shortages. The Department says the new schedule will operate ldquountil further notice.KILLOUGH mdash Members of the Killough branch of the SDLP have hit out at the delay in providing facilities for children in the village. The members say it is completely unfair that every town and village in the area has two or three play areas while Killough has none.ARDGLASS mdash It has been proposed that the new residential home for the elderly in Ardglass should be named Ardview House. The recommendation was supported recently by the Down District Executive Team of the Eastern Health and Social Services Board.SOCCER mdash Cochrane Corry Cup holders Kilmore Rec surrendered their title at Dickson Park, Downpatrick, when arch rivals Annalong Swts came back from the dead with three goals in the last  minutes to win -.Kilmore, with the Junior Shield already under their belts, looked in confident mood after taking a second minute lead and seemed to home and dry when they added a second goal midway through the second half.But Annalong, who fell in the Junior Cup final, showed their determination to avoid a second cup final defeat in the same season by coming back in an exciting last quarter to snatch a superb win..prettyPhoto

title: Mooney misses out as Down set to entertain Tipperary
story: DOWN will go into next Sundayrsquos All-Ireland SFC Qualier against Tipperary without the talismanic Caolan Mooney.The Rostrevor man picked up a red card after lsquobehaving in a way which is dangerous to an opponentrsquo, in last weekrsquos high-octane clash with Armagh at Pairc Esler.The County Board appealed against that decision and the hearing at Croke Park was held on Monday night by the Central Hearings Committee.However, after due process, they found the alleged infraction proven and Mooneyrsquos automatic one-match ban stands.This is a crushing blow for Down.Mooney has been the cornerstone of the Down side over the past few years and his swashbuckling runs from deep have been one of the few high points in recent campaigns.However, Paddy Tallyrsquos side will be strongly fancied to progress.Last Sundayrsquos heartbreaking defeat at Pairc Esler was a bitter pill to swallow for the Down players, but they must now regroup and hit the ground running against a wounded Tipperary outfit.Tipp were soundly beaten - to - by Limerick in the first round of the Munster SFC a fortnight ago and that was a severe below to manager Liam Kearnsrsquo aspirations.A few years back Tipp were regarded as one of the best young sids in Ireland, but they appear to have hit the skid pan and are now there for the taking.They narrowly missed out on promotion to Division  of the ACFL two years ago, but have fallen from grace big time and were relegated back into Division  at the end of March.They have outstanding players in Liam Casey and Steven OrsquoBrien, while rookie Daire Brennan has the potential to become a big name in the sport.Down, on the other hand, will recall their last meeting with Tipp in March of last year when Eamon Burnsrsquo side registered a - to - win at Pairc Esler in their last game of the ACFL Division  campaign.A win that day for Down was not enough to prevent them from relegation, but there have been massive changes in the Mourne team since then.It is expected that out of the  that started last March, only three players from that day are likely to begin the game against Tipperary.Meanwhile, the countyrsquos senior camogie side take on Antrim in the Ulster Championship final at Clones on Sunday.Down go into the showdown full of confidence, given, their - to - win over Derry on Saturday, despite shooting  wides.ldquoGoing forward we are going to have to address those wides, said manager Martina Rooney.ldquoBut look, I am more than happy with the attitude of the girls. They worked very hard from start to finish, maybe dipped a bit during the middle of the second half. But we finished strongly.The only period when Derry looked to have a chance was entering the last quarter when Graacuteinne McGoldrick poached a goal and then added a point to close the gap to - to -.ldquoYes, that was a hairy enough time, but when you need players to stand up, they really did. We brought in a couple of subs as well and they steadied things up, she added.ldquoWe would be happy enough with our overall effort, but there is more in us and we have enough to work on this week..prettyPhoto

title: O’Hagan swoops to conquer Derry
story: A RUTHLESSLY efficient Down side secured their place in the Ulster Championship final against Antrim at the Athletic Grounds, Armagh, on Saturday afternoon.Portaferryrsquos Niamh Mallon was prominent for Down, taking points from play and frees, but it was Clonduffrsquos Paula OrsquoHagan who came good with a goal and a point in the dying stages to halt a Derry comeback in its tracks.Derry opened the scoring with a free after just  seconds, but two unanswered points from the reliable Mallon and Castlewellanrsquos Sorcha McCartan, a member of the countyrsquos highly successful All-Ireland Minor Shield winning squad, gave her side a - to - lead after  minutes.Mairead McNicholl restored parity with a point from play before Derry seized the lead again with a point from play, but this was to be their last score of the half as Down went nap.Three points, including two from play and another from McCartan, catapulted Down into a commanding - to - lead at the interval.Down opened the second half on the front foot and two consecutive frees from Mallon extended their lead to seven points, - to -.However, Derry summoned up an heroic fightback and a goal from Grainne McGoldrick and three unanswered points left just a single point in it with seven minutes remaining.Downrsquos backs were certainly against the wall, but cometh the hour, cometh OrsquoHagan and a pointed free and then a sensational goal put daylight between the sides again with Down easing up in the closing stages to record an impressive five-point win.Down: C McGourty, N Kelly, A Savage, C McGilligan, K McMullan, D Magee, C Rocks, A McAleenan, A Keown , SL Carr, S McCartan , P Gribben , N MallonC Caldwell, F Carr . Subs: D Harrison for McAleenan, O Gribben for Mallon, K Tinnelly for McMullan, N McCullagh for McCartan.Derry: N McQuillan, C Glass, B Niacute Chaiside, S Donaghy, M Kerr, A Niacute Chaiside, Aacute McAllister, G McNicholl , D OrsquoKane, G McGoldrick , S Quinn, M McNicholl , A Quinn, S Graham, M Hegarty.
